1118669601129189376.text: Three+ years and several papers later there's now RFC 8452: AES-GCM-SIV. Want to take advantage of AES-GCM hardware support but dislike AES-GCM exploding if you ever repeat a nonce? Try new AES-GCM-SIV. (Encryption runs at about 75–90% of GCM, decryption should be ~same.)

1003616383526162433.text: Google’s first-generation CT log implementation keeps all data in memory, which doesn’t scale, and also takes a long time to start from cold. The 2nd generation approach, with Trillian, solves this problem.

1003593583956578304.text: From @sleevi_, don’t rely on OCSP stapling to maintain your CT compliance. Doesn’t work in general (although IIS seems to work properly).

1003580872170360832.text: Lots of talk here at CT day about log disqualification. Log can and do fail, and we should accept that normal part of CT log operations. Also, improve the ecosystem to handle the failures smoothly.

1003571468700127232.text: It takes roughly 216 days (or 31 weeks) for a new CT log to become usable, allowing time for initial evaluation, monitoring, and rollout to Chrome clients.

1003570173146796034.text: Chrome currently checks how old it is and turns off CT enforcement 10 weeks after its build date. (This behaviour is intended to support adoption of new CT logs.)
